pwn-execve-sandbox.description: What a kewl sandbox! Seccomp makes it impossible to execute ./flag
pwn-execve-sandbox.name: execve sandbox

pwn-sftp.description: This file server has a sophisticated malloc implementation designed to thwart traditional heap exploitation techniques...
pwn-sftp.name: SFTP

pwn-drive.description: File sharing done the hackers way. Besides just uploading and downloading files, you can process them server side using the full x64 instruction set! Just send us an ELF and we'll run it for you.
pwn-drive.name: Drive

misc-tape.description: We've found this priceless, old magnetic tape in our archives. We dumped the contents, but the data is corrupted and we can't read it. We only have this old tape reader tool, but source code was lost long ago. The program has only 944 bytes, so reversing it should be trivial, right?
misc-tape.name: Tape

crypto-dm-col.description: Can you find a collision in this compression function?
crypto-dm-col.name: DM Collision

pwn-sandbox-compat.description: x86 memory segmentation is easy, just put everything untrusted under 4G.
pwn-sandbox-compat.name: Sandbox compat

misc-feel-it.description: I have a feeling there is a flag there somewhere
misc-feel-it.name: feel it

web-translate.description: Client-side rendering, but not in a browser! Get the flag in ./flag.txt, and seeing the source will likely help.
web-translate.name: translate

misc-phrack.description: I heard Phrack is still kinda relevant. But since when do they include ctf flags?
misc-phrack.name: phrack

crypto-dogestore.description: Secret Cloud Storage System: This is a new system to store your end-to-end encrypted secrets. Now with SHA3 integrity checks!
crypto-dogestore.name: DogeStore

re-keygenme.description: I bet you can't reverse this algorithm!
re-keygenme.name: Keygenme

misc-bookshelf.description: Organize those rectangular things that take physical space!
misc-bookshelf.name: Bookshelf

re-android.description: Win the game 1,000,000 times to get the flag.
re-android.name: Shall we play a game?

crypto-mitm.description: Man in the Middle the communication between the client and the server.
crypto-mitm.name: MITM

re-proprietary.description: The villains are communicating with their own proprietary file format. Figure out what it is.
re-proprietary.name: Proprietary format

crypto-better-zip.description: The legacy ZIP crypto is long broken, so we've fixed it
crypto-better-zip.name: better ZIP

web-cat-chat.description: You discover this cat enthusiast chat app, but the annoying thing about it is that you're always banned when you start talking about dogs. Maybe if you would somehow get to know the admin's password, you could fix that.
web-cat-chat.name: Cat Chat

re-basics.description: You won't find any assembly in this challenge, only C64 BASIC. Once you get the password, the flag is CTF{password}. P.S. The challenge has been tested on the VICE emulator.
re-basics.name: Back to the BASICs

crypto-perfect-secrecy.description: This crypto experiment will help you decrypt an RSA encrypted message.
crypto-perfect-secrecy.name: Perfect Secrecy

misc-wired-csv.description: We have a photo and a CSV file. NOTE: The flag does not follow the CTF{...} format, but is clearly marked as the flag. Please add the CTF{...} around the flag manually when submitting.
misc-wired-csv.name: wired CSV

re-mlwr-part1.description: We have detected weird traffic on our network and we cannot figure out the source. Forensics didn't find anything besides maybe the NTP service binaries which have been modified recently on some hosts. We ran them through the sandboxes and they seem to work as intended, can you do a quick manual pass?
re-mlwr-part1.name: APT42 - Part 1

pwn-mlwr-part2.description: It looks like sensitive data might have been exilftrated. We need to move fast before they shut down their C2 infrastructure. Any chance you can compromise the C2 found in part 1 and see if the data is still there?
pwn-mlwr-part2.name: APT42 - Part 2

web-js-safe-2.description: You stumbled upon someone's "JS Safe" on the web. It's a simple HTML file that can store secrets in the browser's localStorage. This means that you won't be able to extract any secret from it (the secrets are on the computer of the owner), but it looks like it was hand-crafted to work only with the password of the owner...
web-js-safe-2.name: JS Safe 2.0
